definition: Confident trust in God's character and promises—especially in Christ's finished work. Both gift and response (Ephesians 2:8–9; Hebrews 11:1).
God's unearned favor toward humanity, expressed fully in the redemptive work of Christ (Ephesians 2:8; Titus 2:11).
The comprehensive work of God to rescue sinners from judgment and bring them into eternal life (Romans 1:16; John 3:17).
Communication with God—both speaking and listening. Includes adoration, confession, thanksgiving, and supplication (1 Thessalonians 5:17; Philippians 4:6).
The act of ascribing worth to God through praise, thanksgiving, and obedient service (John 4:24; Psalm 95:6).
God's gracious act of removing sin's penalty and restoring relationship (1 John 1:9; Psalm 103:12).
Selfless, sacrificial love that seeks the good of others, exemplified by Christ's death on the cross (1 Corinthians 13:4-7; John 3:16).
Confident expectation based on God's promises, especially the hope of eternal life (Romans 15:13; 1 Peter 1:3).
Wholeness and well-being that comes from being right with God and others (John 14:27; Philippians 4:7).
Deep, abiding happiness that comes from knowing God and experiencing His presence (Psalm 16:11; James 1:2).
God's tender compassion toward those in need, withholding deserved punishment (Lamentations 3:22-23; Luke 6:36).
Right standing before God and right living according to His standards (Romans 1:17; Matthew 5:6).
Being set apart for God's purposes and reflecting His pure, perfect character (1 Peter 1:15-16; Leviticus 20:26).
God-given ability to apply knowledge rightly and make sound judgments (James 1:5; Proverbs 9:10).
Expressing thanks to God for His blessings and faithfulness (1 Thessalonians 5:18; Psalm 100:4).
Recognizing one's dependence on God and valuing others above oneself (Philippians 2:3-4; James 4:6).
Bearing difficulties with calmness and trust in God's timing (James 1:3-4; Romans 5:3-4).
Strength to face challenges with confidence in God's presence and power (Joshua 1:9; 2 Timothy 1:7).
Deep feeling of concern for others' suffering, leading to action (Colossians 3:12; Matthew 9:36).
Willingness to give freely and abundantly, reflecting God's generous nature (2 Corinthians 9:6-7; Proverbs 11:25).
Remaining true to God and others, keeping promises and commitments (Galatians 5:22; Lamentations 3:23).
Turning away from sin and toward God, involving both sorrow and change (Acts 3:19; 2 Corinthians 7:10).
Willing submission to God's will and commands (John 14:15; 1 Samuel 15:22).
Expressing admiration and gratitude to God for who He is and what He has done (Psalm 150:6; Hebrews 13:15).
Praying on behalf of others, following Christ's example as our intercessor (1 Timothy 2:1; Romans 8:34).
Acknowledging sin before God and declaring faith in Christ (1 John 1:9; Romans 10:9-10).
